Keep lots of plates spinning: financial bandits know that the more opaque their operations, the less regulators might detect any wrongdoing. So dodgy entrepreneurs are experts at shuffling their corporate assets — changing names and owners frequently.

BE11:11am

Hm.

BE11:12am

Run several sets of books: once upon a time I bought a substantial Belgian family business in the printing sector which used special software to prepare two sets of accounts — one reflecting the true picture, and one showing a much less profitable state of affairs — for the tax authorities. Fortunately, the vendors were obliged to sell the business based on the latter numbers, so the business was actually much more profitable than it appeared.

11:11 am
BE11:12am

Uh huh?

Tom Dalgleish Swindles are rarely novel and rarely edifying. Who'd be a judge?
BE11:12am

Make it complicated: most people do not understand the technicalities of investing or accounting. Many con artists fool investors by making the apparent complexities of their scheme so esoteric that no one can see the fraud.

BE11:12am

Okay.

BE11:20am

(Bloomberg) -- Earlier this year, an unidentified company
trading on AIM had an Elon Musk moment, posting material
information on social media before it went out on official
channels. The move earned it a fine and a slap on the wrist from
the venue’s regulator.
“We encourage companies to use social media,” Marcus
Stuttard, head of London Stock Exchange’s AIM market for growth
companies, said in an interview, “as long as all existing
investors get the same level of information at the same time.”
The sanction was reflective of a wider push by AIM to rid
itself of its “Wild West” reputation. Companies have raised a
combined 110 billion pounds ($144 billion) since AIM started in
1995. And the venue’s rules have been tightened progressively
over the past decade, according to Andrew Crossley of London
broker Stockdale Securities Ltd.

BE11:20am

Should've expected an Aim blowup within a day or so, in retrospect.

Soundbuy Pricing holding at present........
BE11:25am

Our IP upgrade and addition of WRK to the CL last year was based on
our thesis that US box shipment growth can sustain higher rates (2%+) going forward than it has in the past (0.5%-1.0%) since eCommerce is now a large and growing portion of the mix. While we consider this thesis still valid (box demand rose 2.4% in 2017 and 1.8% YTD), we underestimated the speed and severity of the supply response in the industry to this acceleration in demand. Following 12 new capacity announcements since our upgrade, we now forecast 11% growth in North American capacity from 2019-2022 (including 0.5%/year capacity creep) against our estimate of 2% per year demand growth. We acknowledge that valuation on containerboard stocks likely already reflects these announcements following significant YTD underperformance, but we are incrementally concerned by the pace of recent new supply announcements as well as the fact that Chinese entrants are now entering the US market for the first time. Furthermore, barring a sharper re-acceleration in demand growth, we struggle to identify positive catalysts for our broad containerboard coverage until the overhang of new capacity abates. That said, we expect the pending KS acquisition to act as an idiosyncratic positive catalyst for WRK leading us to maintain our Buy rating.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

It's important to stress that Nine Dragons was the straw, not the .... um .... camel.

BE11:26am

If that makes sense from a cryptozoological perspective.

wayneJ If the camel is already vomiting do you need a straw?
BE11:27am

over the past 15 months we have had 12 new capacity projects announced
with another 7 companies reported to be exploring further new capacity additions. Individually, each of these projects is relatively small (~1% of existing North American capacity), but in aggregate they are likely to result in oversupply at some point in the 2020-2022 time period even if demand growth remains at recent ~2% rates. We acknowledge that we were not prepared for nor did we expect such a rapid industry response to better demand prospects, and this has been a key reason for the underperfromance of containerboard stocks over the past year.

1966AndAllThat Think Chris Marsh may be a director of 20+ companies. https://suite.endole.co.uk/insight/people/11298991-mr-christopher-david-marsh
11:27 am
BE11:27am

That's Goldman. And this is Citi.

BE11:27am

This month alone we’ve seen other announcements from McKinley Paper, which confirmed plans to move forward with its Port Angeles, WA project, as well as New-Indy acquisition of Resolute’s Catawba, SC mill for another containerboard conversion. While the amount of capacity Nine Dragons, New-Indy & McKinley will add is uncertain, we estimate 2020 operating rates could get pushed towards ~90-92% given the announcements. The key question into year-end is how many additional capacity projects we learn of (we expect UFS & potentially PKG to announce capacity plans) and the strength of box demand into 4Q & the crucial E-commerce season.

BE11:28am

You get the idea.

In August, a BT spokesperson said "there are no active plans to sell the business [Openreach]" and we will have greater clarity on this after the appointment of a new CEO.

There's fantasy M&A -- sort of -- from Deutsche on Sage.

Sage Group PLC (SGE:LSE): Last: 559.60, up 13 (+2.38%), High: 563.80, Low: 544.40, Volume: 1.15m
11:42 am
BE11:42am

In the past 2 months Sage has fallen by 16% and now trades at 16x our FY19 eps, which is the low end of its 5 year valuation range. While competition is rising, we believe Sage has a relatively sticky, defensible product set and forecast mid-single % eps CAGR over the next 3 years, along with a 3% yield.
We continue to think ~16x FY19 eps is reasonable, which yields our TP of 540p, only slightly below the current price, hence the upgrade.

Pharma @wayneJ, given the divergent views across Europe wrt mergers and national champions, it's a bit odd to worry about the UK becoming more like France, Gernmany etc. after we leave the EU.
BE11:42am

So far, so meh. But then:

BE11:42am

Given KKR disclosed their offer for mature accounting software player MYOB this week, we believe PE funds are likely examining Sage and we explore this in the note. We struggle to see material value accretion for a PE owner, other than in a Micro Focus style 'asset sweat' scenario, where we believe mid teens equity FCF yields could be realistic, but with a declining top line given lack of investment and with the risk of pricing and share loss due to growing competition.
However, as such an outcome could plausibly be attractive for a PE buyer or activist we would be wary of remaining underweight/ short at this level.

Bonnemort @Pharma - remember Danone, that strategically vital French yogurt maker - while over here it's all for sale

11:47 am
BE11:47am

New LTIPs show an encouraging new focus on cash generation. New long-term management incentive plans have shifted the focus from EPS to FCF, which we believe is positive. Historic cash generation has promised a lot, but rarely delivered. Even at the entry point of management incentives (GBP517m of FCF in the next three years), we believe the current dividend (7.3% yield) is covered, which provides share price support. However, we believe management are far more ambitious than this. If they deliver at the top end of the LTIP (three-year cumulative FCF of GBP689m), we estimate they would generate over a third of the current market cap and likely exit the period at a run rate over GBP300m pa.

Gillibrand When I used to work for Dixons, they wanted a heavy market presence in the broadband sector. Could be linked to telecoms market growing stronger...
BE11:48am

There are many uncertainties in UK retail, but beyond its obvious cyclicality, Dixons Carphone is well positioned. It is a strong market leader with a well advanced multi-channel platform and right-sized property portfolio. This arguably makes it lower risk than many stocks in the sector. We have been impressed with the new CEO’s performance so far and interactions during his previous roles in the sector, and expect the strategy update in December to be positive. The current share price appears to reflect much of the bad news of the new strategy, but none of the good, in our view, with the shares well supported by even the low end of FCF targets.

BE11:48am

There's a strategy day in December. If the new CEO can find a way to ringfence mobile it's sunlit uplands ahead, they say.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

It seems the summer may have been even hotter than we thought. Our own and the Bank of England's forecast for Q3 growth is 0.4% - but the UK delivered this increase in July alone. Some of this may reflect the uplifting events of that month, including the heatwave and the World Cup, though the associated sectors - wholesale and retail trade, accommodation and catering - only accounted for 0.12ppts of the monthly growth rate in July. There was strength elsewhere too. Professional, scientific and technical activity contributed another 0.14ppts, while industrial production added another 0.06ppts.

GBKrona thanks @Penny - together with the new Chair he would really shake things up at BT
BE11:58am

As usual with the UK in recent months, we can read these data in two ways. The optimists will see 3m/3m growth rising to a 18-month high, while the pessimists will see a distinct loss of momentum after a weather-driven spike in activity. Time will tell which interpretation is correct, though we note that the picture is looking up a little elsewhere in Europe. Whether the momentum can be sustained into Q4 is uncertain, but it does seem that there are now upside risks to our own and the BoE's Q3 growth forecasts.

BE11:58am

(@Gillibrand: what have I missed on John Lewis?)

BE12:00pm

Services steady, manufacturing down: Despite a rebound in the August survey data, services activity flat-lined. Industrial production rose, boosted by oil and gas extraction. However, manufacturing contracted on the month, with majority of sub-sectors recording a fall in output.
Hawkish MPC: With upside risks to the MPC's 3Q 0.4%Q forecast, recent
stronger-than-expected inflation prints and robust labour market data, we think the MPC's message next month will be hawkish. However, we see the next hike only in May 2019, once there is more clarity on future relations with Europe.
